title: Things that doesnt work about ranked
body:
-too much emphasis is put on the 10 very first ranked games of a player
-the system keep placing players lower every season meaning that the skill level needed to get out of tiers like silver might be higher every season
-promos feel kinda useless and unnecessarily give stress to the player
-games lost at 0 lp have too much impact on the future lp gains and losses of a player
-5th divisions are too much of a melting pot of players and tend to create some kind of elo hell
-the way ranked is made force a highly time-consuming grind if you want to make any real progress in rank
-it feel like when you win too much in a row you get a forced loss streak maybe because your put in a 1v9 carrying spot with teamates way worse than you
-the lp gains and losses sometimes feel really punishing and prevent any attempt to climb
-you're only 1/5 of your team and let's face it, it's kinda hard to really solo carry a game when your teammates don,t work with you for the win
-Bad players, afk and troll have too much impact on the own climbing of a player, for example, you lose the same lp as the troll even when you were the best player on the team and could have won with a decent team
-New players inserted in ranked games with experienced players really hurt the matchmaking quality
-Sometimes, the difference in ranks in one game is just too much and it sometimes make the games really one-sided
- The rank distribution is really wrong and put too much players in the same low elo spot, here's some stats  about the playerbase by tier from league of graphs :
Bronze 22,23%
Silver **40,34%** i mean, really? maybe add an electrum tier?
Gold 26,20%

here's the total elitist part :
Platinum 8,87%
Diamond  2,30%

yup, don't ever dream of it :
Master 0,04%
Challenger 0,02%

This is impossible due to queue dodging losing you LP. So one could win 1 game, then dodge 3 in a row (3+9+9) and go back where he was despite his MMR being increased. Needless to say, with enough dedication one could stay silver with challenger MMR just by queue dodging after every win.

It's possible to have a BETTER match than what is current, it's not going to be perfect. LP rank at the moment (and a lot of the time, not all) spends too much time lagging behind MMR, from things like current promos/demotion protection, and too wide of a variation between win/loss values. Moving up and down in LP rank should be LESS different than MMR ups/downs after each game. 

For example in an extreme situation, if you go on a massive losing streak, you should be moving down rank significantly, and vice versa. Currently if you win a lot of games, your LP rate gets so padded that you can lose a lot yet stay close to the same division. The opposite is true if you lose a lot first, your climb in the future is so halted that it takes twice as long to move up divisions. 

As a result people get stuck in certain ranks, whether it's silver 5 players taking forever to move up, or diamond  5 players taking forever to move down, and no one actually plays against people in their same division. If division rank was a closer indicator of your skill level, it would be a less frustrating and more fun/satisfying system overall.

I think the champion grade you get should be taken into account in LP calculations. In my experience, the grade represents performance quite accurately.

When winning a game (numbers for illustrative purposes):
S = greatly increased LP gain (+15)
A = slightly increased LP gain (+12)
B = normal LP gain (+10)
C = slightly decreased LP gain (+8)
D = greatly decreased LP gain (+5)
When losing a game:
S = greatly decreased LP loss (–5)
A = slightly decreased LP loss (–8)
...
D = greatly increased LP loss (–15)

Can you imagine how toxic it would be if people were stealing all farm and trying to ks everything just to get more LP? This would also cause more kda whores that would never go in and die for an initiation, just so they don't get a bad grade. Sometimes I get a c, but I know I did my job because I played a tank and peeled, or absorbed damage for my team.

It's easy to fix, everyone knows it, but Riot simply won't do it.


Step 1.

**Make that you can only be matched with and against players of your own Tier. **

_I can live in a world that I need to play against a Plat1 if I'm a Plat3 seems on my spectrum, and I feel I can bet him. But don't put me to carry 4 Gold5 against a team full of D1s, that's just ridiculous._


Step 2.

**Make a base LP value for win and losses, but also add LP bonus and penalties for certain attitudes.**

_I get it I lost this match, and I deserve to lose some LP. But why the hell I've lost the same amount of LP as the guy who flamed me all game, rage quit 10 min into the game because he was ganked twice._


Step 3.

**Ban new champions from ranked for at least, I'm talking minimum 2 weeks.**

_Dude, you have normals, you have practice tools, you have bots, hell you even have Dynamic Queue. Why do you need to try your new champion on my promos? I really think is too selfish to do something like that and should be considered cancerous._

I completely agree with you.

>That is needed to ensure it doesn't take 200 games for everyone to get to where they belong. Also, remember that it isn't a huge drop off between first 10 games and next 10, it is a gradual drop off of how much mmr you gain and lose.

Those first 10 matches determine whenever you'll be placed in the depths of Bronze or get Gold outright.

There does NOT exist a case where you could be able to make such a tremendous difference within 10 games outside placements.

>Placement games are +/- 48-50 mmr. Afterwards, mmr change goes down to 24 and then 12.

>There is no fix for this.

Except for the obvious fix of not gaining/losing LP solely based on win/loss and mmr as has been mentioned thousands if not millions of times before and other games already do...

>It has been such a huge failure

How has it failed?

>Also, stop pretending individual performance is remotely as easy to measure in a moba as it is in overwatch. You are grasping at straws.

What? How is it any harder? If anything I suspect it's easier.

_How_ has it failed? You're once again just asserting that it did. You did nothing to answer the question. And on top of that you made yet another assumption (that Riot dumped a ton of resources into it) you have no proof of. Can you even provide reasonable evidence supporting the possibility of your claims?

> [{quoted}](name=magewick,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=ZmfIKgFP,comment-id=0009000100010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-11-24T18:32:10.999+0000)

(And don't bring in the overwatch crap, it is irrelavent and just makes you look desperate). Every example of an individual performance system in dota or league so far have been so bad that the developers gave up on it.

i mean, it's not really like a team sport, sure it's totally fine to count only winrate when you always have the same teammates but in the case of solo/duo queue you always get a different team with different players, a win/loss only system can't really be accurate in that case. No we didn't. The grading system was never meant to be a part of LP or MMR and so never has been. They don't give it much mind or focus and don't attempt to fine tune it much if at all like they could. It's heavily focused on k/d/a and cs, minorly affected by a couple other things. It could be so much better, but they just don't care enough because it's not a big deal.

If actually done well and kept up with it could absolutely work. As I said, _some other games already do it._

>The grading system was riot's attempt at creating a formula which could eventually replace mmr

Says you with no proof whatsoever...

>If they had kept updating it like they tried to initially, it would be in no better state than it is now.

Says you with no proof whatsoever...

>Performance based grading simply does not work in a moba.

Says you with no proof whatsoever...

>That is why only failing mobas like hots try it as a cheap attempt at grabbing more players while dota and league stay with mmr.

Wait hots does it? I was talking about Overwatch. My understanding is that it's a small effect, as it should be, but does certainly matter and at least somewhat work from what I can tell.

In team games I feel it's an absolute necessity. Without it luck is far more important than skill as to whether or not you go up or down in rank within a certain range, the edges of which are a bit far apart (like more than an entire division typically) and where your skill (or lack thereof) eventually is different enough to overcome the fact that you're just 1 person on a team of 5 (or 6, or whatever depending on the game/mode).

>Because you have been providing sources for everything you say. Why do you think riot tried so hard to create a formula that judged individual performance?

So you're just assuming.

I'm 99.999% sure you're wrong because _they made an entire new system known as champion mastery to use the grading system_ and it'd be silly at best to do that _just to disguise it._ And here is where you say "why not use it for both?" And I say "technically possible, extremely unlikely, and ya know they _would've said something about it because they aren't evil villains trying to hide their dastardly plot."_

>overwatch is not a moba. No serious moba does it.

It isn't about being a moba or not. All that matters in this regard is team game vs individual game. Pure MMR/ELO is a terrible way to rate individuals playing a team game. I can explain why if you want, but I feel like it's pretty obvious.

Also you don't get to decide which mobas are "serious" and which aren't. Also there aren't a lot of mobas. Also very few games period have ever tried individual performance affected rating systems within team competition because yeah it's complex, nuanced, a good bit of work, and inherently imperfect. It's still better and totally worth it. But just using the old standard is free, minimal effort, and there's safety in numbers (aka "No serious moba does it" defense).

>They weren't disguising it at all. They straight up said the grading was made to reflect individual contribution to team performance. Originally, it even broke down exactly what percentage of the mastery points your own contribution accounted for.

Gonna need some major proof here. I'll wait.

>Actually, it is very important because of what is and what is not possible in a moba vs in another game. What you are proposing is straight up impossible to do in a moba. You have to stop living in your own fantasy world. There is no magic formula which can calculate individual contribution well enough to be a better rating system than mmr.

It's impossible to do it _perfectly_ either way for _any_ type of game. Even in a 1v1 game ELO is not a _perfect_ system. That isn't the point. Incorporating some amount of individual performance metric to simply influence the degree you gain and lose rating would be an easy improvement even if only halfway decently done. MMR systems are simply that awful at rating individuals in team settings. Most people are just so used to it that like you they accept it as somehow ok. It isn't ok. It's wildly bad.

>I never decided, I played all of them.

It doesn't matter if you played them or not. You alone do not get to decree which are serious or not. No one person does. Even popularity alone doesn't decide that. _Nothing_ decides that for everyone. Each person decides how _they_ feel about it and that's it. It's fine for _you_ to not think it's "serious." It's not fine for you to tell _me_ that it isn't "serious." And for the record, I actually agree with you about hots. It just doesn't matter in this discussion anyways.

>Also, league already tried individual performance and failed.

Neither of those things is true as far as I've seen. Certainly not if you're talking about champion mastery. Yes it's clearly flawed in a number of ways, but I wouldn't call it a failure at all. I think if Riot decided to use it to affect MMR they'd take it a little more seriously, tune it, get feedback on it, and keep tuning it over time. They simply haven't decided to do that and I doubt they will any time soon sadly.

>They say it straight up in the support section:
Riot never hid the fact that the grading system was a way for them to attempt at measuring your own performance.

You're completely right in regards to it literally being that. But I assumed we were still talking about it in the context of it having anything to do with MMR. What they said has nothing to do with MMR. You haven't remotely proven that they ever intended to use it to affect MMR (or even LP) in _any way, shape, or form._ When you have proof that they did, come share it.

>This has never been the case in a moba.

No direct bearing on if it _could_ become the case. It's only related in the sense that change is hard, making something new takes effort, people will be scared of change, blah blah all that typical stuff. Nothing is inherently wrong with doing it.

>Individual performance metrics are simply too hard to evaluate well

I strongly disagree and I don't think either of us can convince the other on this issue. But regardless, that's not even terribly relevant. What matters more is that current MMR systems are _so stupendously terrible for team games that even a bad individual performance system slightly influencing one is an upgrade._

>Riot took it very seriously and tried to tune the mastery system for over a year without much success.

According to who? I certainly didn't see that from Riot. They certainly didn't sound like they were fine tuning it after the first month. Where are you even remotely getting this idea from?

>Dota inhouse league have been trying for many years abeit on a smaller scale without any success.

I have zero knowledge about such a thing. But based on how you see League's champion mastery system and your out of nowhere assumption about Riot's intentions for it I honestly have no faith in your assessment of the situation so... *shrug*

If you win a lot your mmr rises a lot. Which put you against higher mmr players than before. Which in turn gives you more LP if you win.
However, you might go on a loss streak if that hightened mmr is too much for you to handle or adapt too. In that, you may have the skills to play at that lvl, but because you are used to playing against lower mmr players you make moves to counter something that doesn't exist any more, setting you back more than needed. Gradual changes, or the ability to quickly adapt might help there. But then, thats what happens after the loss streak.
